baseline: Whitman wrote Democratic Vistas in answer to criticism of universal suffrage and full democracy of Thomas Carlyle in Latter-Day Pamphlets, who considered the popular democratic system to be too many rights given to uneducated masses of the people, as rule should be kept in the hands of highly educated people and aristocrats.

prompts: Liberal democracy , western - style democracy , or substantive democracy is a form of
baseline: Liberal democracy, western-style democracy, or substantive democracy is a form of government that combines the organization of a representative democracy with ideas of liberal political philosophy.

prompts: Common elements within a liberal democracy are : elections between
baseline: Common elements within a liberal democracy are: elections between or among multiple distinct political parties, a separation of powers into different branches of government, the rule of law in everyday life as part of an open society, a market economy with private property, universal suffrage, and the equal protection of human rights, civil rights, civil liberties, and political freedoms for all citizens.

prompts: Substantive democracy refers to substantive rights and substantive laws , which can include substantive equality ,
baseline: Substantive democracy refers to substantive rights and substantive laws, which can include substantive equality, the equality of outcome for subgroups in society.

prompts: A liberal democracy may take various and mixed constitutional forms : it may be a constitutional monarchy
baseline: A liberal democracy may take various and mixed constitutional forms: it may be a constitutional monarchy or a republic.

prompts: Liberal democracy traces its origins —
baseline: Liberal democracy traces its origins—and its name—to the Age of Enlightenment.

prompts: After a period of expansion in the second half of the 20th century , liberal democracy became a prevalent political
baseline: After a period of expansion in the second half of the 20th century, liberal democracy became a prevalent political system in the world.

prompts: Liberal democracy emphasizes the separation of
baseline: Liberal democracy emphasizes the separation of powers, an independent judiciary, and a system of checks and balances between branches of government.

prompts: Liberal democracy traces its origins —
baseline: Liberal democracy traces its origins—and its name—to 18th-century Europe, during the Age of Enlightenment.

prompts: The possibility of democracy had not been a seriously considered
baseline: The possibility of democracy had not been a seriously considered political theory since classical antiquity and the widely held belief was that democracies would be inherently unstable and chaotic in their policies due to the changing whims of the people.

prompts: It was further believed that democracy was contrary to human nature , as human beings were seen to be inherently
baseline: It was further believed that democracy was contrary to human nature, as human beings were seen to be inherently evil, violent and in need of a strong leader to restrain their destructive impulses.

prompts: The conservative monarchists who opposed liberalism and democracy saw themselves as defenders
baseline: The conservative monarchists who opposed liberalism and democracy saw themselves as defenders of traditional values and the natural order of things and their criticism of democracy seemed vindicated when Napoleon Bonaparte took control of the young French Republic, reorganized it into the first French Empire and proceeded to conquer most of Europe.

prompts: Napoleon was eventually defeated and the Holy Alliance was formed in Europe to
baseline: Napoleon was eventually defeated and the Holy Alliance was formed in Europe to prevent any further spread of liberalism or democracy.

prompts: The Dominions of the British Empire became laboratories for liberal
baseline: The Dominions of the British Empire became laboratories for liberal democracy from the mid 19th century onward.

prompts: Ståhlberg ( 1865–1952 ) , the first President of the Republic of Finland , defined Finland 's anchoring
baseline: Ståhlberg (1865–1952), the first President of the Republic of Finland, defined Finland's anchoring as a country defending liberal democracy.

prompts: Reforms and revolutions helped move most European countries
baseline: Reforms and revolutions helped move most European countries towards liberal democracy.

prompts: At the same time , a number of non - liberal ideologies developed that took the
baseline: At the same time, a number of non-liberal ideologies developed that took the concept of liberal democracy and made it their own.

prompts: The political spectrum changed ; traditional monarchy became more and more
baseline: The political spectrum changed; traditional monarchy became more and more a fringe view and liberal democracy became more and more mainstream.

prompts: By the end of the 19th century , liberal democracy was no longer only
baseline: By the end of the 19th century, liberal democracy was no longer only a liberal idea, but an idea supported by many different ideologies.

prompts: After World War I and especially after World War II , liberal democracy achieved a dominant position
baseline: After World War I and especially after World War II, liberal democracy achieved a dominant position among theories of government and is now endorsed by the vast majority of the political spectrum.

prompts: Although liberal democracy was originally put forward by Enlightenment liberals , the relationship between democracy and liberalism has been controversial since the
baseline: Although liberal democracy was originally put forward by Enlightenment liberals, the relationship between democracy and liberalism has been controversial since the beginning and was problematized in the 20th century.

prompts: In his book Freedom and Equality in a Liberal Democratic State , Jasper Doomen posited that freedom and
baseline: In his book Freedom and Equality in a Liberal Democratic State, Jasper Doomen posited that freedom and equality are necessary for a liberal democracy.

prompts: In his book The End of History and the Last Man , Francis Fukuyama says that since the
baseline: In his book The End of History and the Last Man, Francis Fukuyama says that since the French Revolution, liberal democracy has repeatedly proven to be a fundamentally better system (ethically, politically, economically) than any of the alternatives, and that democracy will become more and more prevalent in the long term, although it may suffer temporary setbacks.

prompts: The research institute Freedom House today simply defines liberal democracy as
baseline: The research institute Freedom House today simply defines liberal democracy as an electoral democracy also protecting civil liberties.

prompts: The common justification for these limits is that they are
baseline: The common justification for these limits is that they are necessary to guarantee the existence of democracy, or the existence of the freedoms themselves.

prompts: Opinion is divided on how far democracy can extend to include the
baseline: Opinion is divided on how far democracy can extend to include the enemies of democracy in the democratic process.

prompts: If relatively small numbers of people are excluded from such freedoms
baseline: If relatively small numbers of people are excluded from such freedoms for these reasons, a country may still be seen as a liberal democracy.

prompts: At least in theory , opponents of democracy are also allowed due process under
baseline: At least in theory, opponents of democracy are also allowed due process under the rule of law.

prompts: For a political regime to be considered a liberal democracy
baseline: For a political regime to be considered a liberal democracy it must contain in its governing over a nation-state the provision of civil rights- the non-discrimination in the provision of public goods such as justice, security, education and health- in addition to, political rights- the guarantee of free and fair electoral contests, which allow the winners of such contests to determine policy subject to the constraints established by other rights, when these are provided- and property rights- which protect asset holders and investors against expropriation by the state or other groups.

prompts: In this way , liberal democracy is set apart from electoral
baseline: In this way, liberal democracy is set apart from electoral democracy, as free and fair elections – the hallmark of electoral democracy – can be separated from equal treatment and non-discrimination – the hallmarks of liberal democracy.

prompts: In liberal democracy , an elected government can not discriminate against specific individuals
baseline: In liberal democracy, an elected government cannot discriminate against specific individuals or groups when it administers justice, protects basic rights such as freedom of assembly and free speech, provides for collective security, or distributes economic and social benefits.

prompts: According to Seymour Martin Lipset , although they are not part of the system of government as such , a modicum of individual and economic freedoms , which result in the formation
baseline: According to Seymour Martin Lipset, although they are not part of the system of government as such, a modicum of individual and economic freedoms, which result in the formation of a significant middle class and a broad and flourishing civil society, are seen as pre-conditions for liberal democracy.

prompts: For countries without a strong tradition of democratic majority rule , the introduction of free elections alone has rarely been sufficient to achieve a transition from
baseline: For countries without a strong tradition of democratic majority rule, the introduction of free elections alone has rarely been sufficient to achieve a transition from dictatorship to democracy; a wider shift in the political culture and gradual formation of the institutions of democratic government are needed.

prompts: There are various examples — for instance , in Latin America — of countries that were able to sustain democracy only temporarily
baseline: There are various examples—for instance, in Latin America—of countries that were able to sustain democracy only temporarily or in a limited fashion until wider cultural changes established the conditions under which democracy could flourish.

prompts: The term means in essence that all sides in a democracy share a common commitment
baseline: The term means in essence that all sides in a democracy share a common commitment to its basic values.

prompts: One requirement of liberal democracy is political equality amongst voters ( ensuring that all voices and all votes count equally ) and that these can properly influence government policy ,
baseline: One requirement of liberal democracy is political equality amongst voters (ensuring that all voices and all votes count equally) and that these can properly influence government policy, requiring quality procedure and quality content of debate that provides an accountable result, this may apply within elections or to procedures between elections.

prompts: The concept of freedom used in the survey is closely connected to liberal democracy
baseline: The concept of freedom used in the survey is closely connected to liberal democracy.

prompts: One observation is that democracy became
baseline: One observation is that democracy became widespread only after the Industrial Revolution and the introduction of capitalism.

prompts: On the other hand , the Industrial Revolution started in England which
baseline: On the other hand, the Industrial Revolution started in England which was one of the most democratic nations for its time within its own borders, but this democracy was very limited and did not apply to the colonies which contributed significantly to the wealth.

prompts: There are also other studies suggesting that more democracy increases economic freedom ,
baseline: There are also other studies suggesting that more democracy increases economic freedom, although a few find no or even a small negative effect.

prompts: Some argue that economic growth due to its empowerment of citizens will ensure a transition to
baseline: Some argue that economic growth due to its empowerment of citizens will ensure a transition to democracy in countries such as Cuba.

prompts: A 2006 meta - analysis found that democracy has no direct effect
baseline: A 2006 meta-analysis found that democracy has no direct effect on economic growth.

prompts: Democracy is associated with higher human
baseline: Democracy is associated with higher human capital accumulation, lower inflation, lower political instability and higher economic freedom.

prompts: One argument for democracy is that by creating a system where
baseline: One argument for democracy is that by creating a system where the public can remove administrations, without changing the legal basis for government, democracy aims at reducing political uncertainty and instability and assuring citizens that however much they may disagree with present policies, they will be given a regular chance to change those who are in power, or change policies with which they disagree.

prompts: One notable feature of liberal democracies is that their opponents
baseline: One notable feature of liberal democracies is that their opponents (those groups who wish to abolish liberal democracy) rarely win elections.

prompts: Advocates use this as an argument to support their view that
baseline: Advocates use this as an argument to support their view that liberal democracy is inherently stable and can usually only be overthrown by external force, while opponents argue that the system is inherently stacked against them despite its claims to impartiality.

prompts: In the past , it was feared that democracy could
baseline: In the past, it was feared that democracy could be easily exploited by leaders with dictatorial aspirations, who could get themselves elected into power.

prompts: By definition , a liberal democracy implies that power is
baseline: By definition, a liberal democracy implies that power is not concentrated.

prompts: If the democracy is attacked , then no consent is usually required for defensive operations
baseline: If the democracy is attacked, then no consent is usually required for defensive operations.

prompts: Research by the World Bank suggests that political institutions are extremely important in determining the prevalence of
baseline: Research by the World Bank suggests that political institutions are extremely important in determining the prevalence of corruption: (long term) democracy, parliamentary systems, political stability and freedom of the press are all associated with lower corruption.

prompts: Prominent economist Amartya Sen has noted that no functioning democracy has ever
baseline: Prominent economist Amartya Sen has noted that no functioning democracy has ever suffered a large scale famine.

prompts: Democracy correlates with a higher
baseline: Democracy correlates with a higher score on the Human Development Index and a lower score on the human poverty index.

prompts: Several health indicators ( life expectancy and infant and maternal mortality ) have a stronger and
baseline: Several health indicators (life expectancy and infant and maternal mortality) have a stronger and more significant association with democracy than they have with GDP per capita, rise of the public sector or income inequality.

prompts: There are various criticisms of the theory , including at least as
baseline: There are various criticisms of the theory, including at least as many refutations as alleged proofs of the theory, some 200 deviant cases, failure to treat democracy as a multidimensional concept and that correlation is not causation.

prompts: Rudolph Rummel 's Power Kills says that liberal democracy
baseline: Rudolph Rummel's Power Kills says that liberal democracy, among all types of regimes, minimizes political violence and is a method of nonviolence.

baseline: Rummel attributes this firstly to democracy instilling an attitude of tolerance of differences, an acceptance of losing and a positive outlook towards conciliation and compromise.

baseline: The characteristics of liberal democracies are correlated with increased political stability, lower corruption, better management of resources, and better health indicators such as life expectancy and infant mortality.

baseline: However, actual research shows that democracies are more likely to win wars than non-democracies.

baseline: Enemy soldiers may more easily surrender to democracies since they can expect comparatively good treatment.

baseline: Refugee crises almost always occur in non-democracies.

baseline: Political campaigning in representative democracies can favor the rich due to campaign costs, a form of plutocracy where only a very small number of wealthy individuals can actually affect government policy in their favor and toward plutonomy.

baseline: They argue that media coverage in democracies simply reflects public preferences and does not entail censorship.

baseline: By definition, modern liberal democracies allow for regular changes of government.

baseline: Homosexual acts were widely criminalised in democracies until several decades ago and in some democracies like Ghana, Kenya, Tanzania, Tunisia, Nigeria, and Malaysia, they still are, reflecting the religious or sexual mores of the majority.

baseline: Because of this, he said that multi-party democracies under capitalism are always distorted and anti-democratic, their operation merely furthering the class interests of the owners of the means of production, and the bourgeois class becomes wealthy through a drive to appropriate the surplus-value of the creative labours of the working class.

baseline: They suggest that liberal democracies introduce more authoritarian measures to counter authoritarianism itself and cite monitoring elections and more control on media in an effort to stop the agenda of undemocratic views.

baseline: Various authors have also analysed the authoritarian means that are used by liberal democracies to defend economic liberalism and the power of political elites.

prompts: Democracy ( from Ancient Greek : δημοκρατία , romanized :   dēmokratía , dēmos ' people ' and kratos ' rule ' ) is a system of
baseline: Democracy (from Ancient Greek: δημοκρατία, romanized: dēmokratía, dēmos 'people' and kratos 'rule') is a system of government in which state power is vested in the people or the general population of a state.

prompts: Under a minimalist definition of democracy , rulers are elected through competitive elections
baseline: Under a minimalist definition of democracy, rulers are elected through competitive elections while more expansive definitions link democracy to guarantees of civil liberties and human rights in addition to competitive elections.

prompts: In a direct democracy , the people have the direct authority
baseline: In a direct democracy, the people have the direct authority to deliberate and decide legislation.

prompts: In a representative democracy , the people choose governing officials through
baseline: In a representative democracy, the people choose governing officials through elections to do so.

prompts: Features of democracy oftentimes include freedom of assembly , association , personal property , freedom of religion and speech , citizenship , consent of the governed , voting rights
baseline: Features of democracy oftentimes include freedom of assembly, association, personal property, freedom of religion and speech, citizenship, consent of the governed, voting rights, freedom from unwarranted governmental deprivation of the right to life and liberty, and minority rights.

prompts: The notion of democracy has evolved considerably over time
baseline: The notion of democracy has evolved considerably over time.

prompts: Throughout history , one can find evidence of direct democracy , in which communities make decisions through popular
baseline: Throughout history, one can find evidence of direct democracy, in which communities make decisions through popular assembly.

prompts: Today , the dominant form of democracy is representative democracy ,
baseline: Today, the dominant form of democracy is representative democracy, where citizens elect government officials to govern on their behalf such as in a parliamentary or presidential democracy.

prompts: In the common variant of liberal democracy , the powers of the majority are exercised within the framework
baseline: In the common variant of liberal democracy, the powers of the majority are exercised within the framework of a representative democracy, but a constitution and supreme court limit the majority and protect the minority—usually through securing the enjoyment by all of certain individual rights, such as freedom of speech or freedom of association.

prompts: Western democracy , as distinct from that which existed in antiquity ,
baseline: Western democracy, as distinct from that which existed in antiquity, is generally considered to have originated in city-states such as those in Classical Athens and the Roman Republic, where various degrees of enfranchisement of the free male population were observed.

prompts: Democracy contrasts with forms of government where power is not vested in the general
baseline: Democracy contrasts with forms of government where power is not vested in the general population of a state, such as authoritarian systems.

prompts: According to the V - Dem Democracy indices and The Economist Democracy Index , less than half the world 's population lives in a democracy
baseline: According to the V-Dem Democracy indices and The Economist Democracy Index, less than half the world's population lives in a democracy as of 2022.

prompts: Although democracy is generally understood to be defined by voting ,
baseline: Although democracy is generally understood to be defined by voting, no consensus exists on a precise definition of democracy.

prompts: Karl Popper says that the " classical " view of democracy is , " in brief , the theory that democracy is the rule of the people , and that the people have a right to
baseline: Karl Popper says that the "classical" view of democracy is, "in brief, the theory that democracy is the rule of the people, and that the people have a right to rule".

prompts: One study identified 2,234 adjectives used to describe democracy in the
baseline: One study identified 2,234 adjectives used to describe democracy in the English language.

prompts: For example , in a representative democracy , every vote has ( in theory ) equal weight , and the freedom of eligible citizens is secured by legitimised rights
baseline: For example, in a representative democracy, every vote has (in theory) equal weight, and the freedom of eligible citizens is secured by legitimised rights and liberties which are typically enshrined in a constitution, while other uses of "democracy" may encompass direct democracy, in which citizens vote on issues directly.

prompts: According to the United Nations , democracy " provides an environment that
baseline: According to the United Nations, democracy "provides an environment that respects human rights and fundamental freedoms, and in which the freely expressed will of people is exercised."

prompts: One theory holds that democracy requires three fundamental principles : upward control ( sovereignty residing at the lowest levels of authority ) , political equality , and social norms by which individuals and institutions only consider acceptable acts that
baseline: One theory holds that democracy requires three fundamental principles: upward control (sovereignty residing at the lowest levels of authority), political equality, and social norms by which individuals and institutions only consider acceptable acts that reflect the first two principles of upward control and political equality.

prompts: Legal equality , political freedom and rule of law are often identified by commentators as
baseline: Legal equality, political freedom and rule of law are often identified by commentators as foundational characteristics for a well-functioning democracy.

prompts: Though the term " democracy " is typically used in the context
baseline: Though the term "democracy" is typically used in the context of a  political state, the principles also are potentially applicable to private organisations, such as clubs, societies and firms.

prompts: Majority rule involves a competitive approach , opposed to consensus democracy
baseline: Majority rule involves a competitive approach, opposed to consensus democracy, creating the need that elections, and generally deliberation, be substantively and procedurally "fair"," i.e. just and equitable.

prompts: It has also been suggested that a basic feature of democracy is the capacity of all voters to participate freely and fully

baseline: With its emphasis on notions of social contract and the  collective will of all the voters, democracy can also be characterised as a form of political collectivism because it is defined as a form of government in which all eligible citizens have an equal say in lawmaking.

prompts: Republics , though often popularly associated with democracy because of the shared principle of rule
baseline: Republics, though often popularly associated with democracy because of the shared principle of rule by consent of the governed, are not necessarily democracies, as republicanism does not specify how the people are to rule.

baseline: Republican theorists linked democracy to small size: as political units grew in size, the likelihood increased that the government would turn despotic.

baseline: Forms of democracy occurred organically in societies around the world that had no contact with each other.

baseline: The term democracy first appeared in ancient Greek political and philosophical thought in the city-state of Athens during classical antiquity.

prompts: Under Cleisthenes , what is generally held as the first
baseline: Under Cleisthenes, what is generally held as the first example of a type of democracy in 508–507 BC was established in Athens.

prompts: Cleisthenes is referred to as "
baseline: Cleisthenes is referred to as "the father of Athenian democracy".

prompts: The first attested use of the word democracy is found in prose works
baseline: The first attested use of the word democracy is found in prose works of the 430s BC, such as Herodotus' Histories, but its usage was older by several decades, as two Athenians born in the 470s were named Democrates, a new political name—likely in support of democracy—given at a time of debates over constitutional issues in Athens.

prompts: Athenian democracy took the form of a direct democracy , and it had two distinguishing features
baseline: Athenian democracy took the form of a direct democracy, and it had two distinguishing features: the random selection of ordinary citizens to fill the few existing government administrative and judicial offices, and a legislative assembly consisting of all Athenian citizens.

prompts: Athenian democracy was not only direct in the sense that decisions were made by the assembled
baseline: Athenian democracy was not only direct in the sense that decisions were made by the assembled people, but also the most direct in the sense that the people through the assembly, boule and courts of law controlled the entire political process and a large proportion of citizens were involved constantly in the public business.

prompts: Even though the Roman Republic contributed significantly to many aspects of democracy , only a minority of Romans were citizens with votes
baseline: Even though the Roman Republic contributed significantly to many aspects of democracy, only a minority of Romans were citizens with votes in elections for representatives.

baseline: In addition, the overthrow of the Roman Kingdom was the first case in the Western world of a polity being formed with the explicit purpose of being a republic, although it didn't have much of a democracy.

prompts: This democracy continues to the present
baseline: This democracy continues to the present day and is the world's oldest standing representative democracy.

baseline: In Poland, noble democracy was characterized by an increase in the activity of the middle nobility, which wanted to increase their share in exercising power at the expense of the magnates.

baseline: 20th-century transitions to liberal democracy have come in successive "waves of democracy", variously resulting from wars, revolutions, decolonisation, and religious and economic circumstances.

baseline: A subsequent wave of democratisation brought substantial gains toward true liberal democracy for many states, dubbed "third wave of democracy".

baseline: He also thought that there was a good and a bad variant of each system (he considered democracy to be the degenerate counterpart to timocracy).

baseline: A common view among early and renaissance Republican theorists was that democracy could only survive in small political communities.

baseline: Democracy was therefore highly fragile and rare historically, as it could only survive in small political units, which due to their size were vulnerable to conquest by larger political units.

baseline: Among modern political theorists, there are three contending conceptions of democracy: aggregative democracy, deliberative democracy, and radical democracy.

baseline: The theory of aggregative democracy claims that the aim of the democratic processes is to solicit citizens' preferences and aggregate them together to determine what social policies society should adopt.

baseline: Different variants of aggregative democracy exist.

baseline: Under minimalism, democracy is a system of government in which citizens have given teams of political leaders the right to rule in periodic elections.

baseline: According to the theory of direct democracy, on the other hand, citizens should vote directly, not through their representatives, on legislative proposals.

baseline: He uses the term polyarchy to refer to societies in which there exists a certain set of institutions and procedures which are perceived as leading to such democracy.

baseline: Deliberative democracy is based on the notion that democracy is government by deliberation.

baseline: Unlike aggregative democracy, deliberative democracy holds that, for a democratic decision to be legitimate, it must be preceded by authentic deliberation, not merely the aggregation of preferences that occurs in voting.

baseline: Citizens assemblies are considered by many scholars as practical examples of deliberative democracy, with a recent OECD report identifying citizens assemblies as an increasingly popular mechanism to involve citizens in governmental decision-making.

baseline: Radical democracy is based on the idea that there are hierarchical and oppressive power relations that exist in society.

baseline: Democracy's role is to make visible and challenge those relations by allowing for difference, dissent and antagonisms in decision-making processes.

baseline: World's states coloured by systems of government:  Parliamentary systems: Head of government is elected or nominated by and accountable to the legislature   Constitutional monarchy with a ceremonial monarch   Parliamentary republic with a ceremonial president   Parliamentary republic with an executive president  Presidential system: Head of government (president) is popularly elected and independent of the legislature   Presidential republic  Hybrid systems:   Semi-presidential republic: Executive president is independent of the legislature; head of government is appointed by the president and is accountable to the legislature   Assembly-independent republic: Head of government (president or directory) is elected by the legislature, but is not accountable to it    Semi-constitutional monarchy: Monarch holds significant executive or legislative power   Absolute monarchy: Monarch has unlimited power   One-party state: Power is constitutionally linked to a single political party   Military junta: Committee of military leaders controls the government; constitutional provisions are suspended   Provisional government: No constitutionally defined basis to current regime   Dependent territories and places without governments  Note: this chart represent de jure systems of government, not the de facto degree of democracy.vte

baseline: One form of democracy is direct democracy, in which all eligible citizens have active participation in the political decision making, for example voting on policy initiatives directly.

baseline: The use of a lot system, a characteristic of Athenian democracy, is a feature of some versions of direct democracies.

baseline: Under a parliamentary democracy, government is exercised by delegation to an executive ministry and subject to ongoing review, checks and balances by the legislative parliament elected by the people.

baseline: An important feature of the parliamentary democracy is the concept of the "loyal opposition".

baseline: Presidential Democracy is a system where the public elects the president through an election.

baseline: A semi-presidential system is a system of democracy in which the government includes both a prime minister and a president.

prompts: The term republic has many different meanings , but today often refers to a representative
baseline: The term republic has many different meanings, but today often refers to a representative democracy with an elected head of state, such as a president, serving for a limited term, in contrast to states with a hereditary monarch as a head of state, even if these states also are representative democracies with an elected or appointed head of government such as a prime minister.

prompts: The Founding Fathers of the United States often criticised direct democracy ,
baseline: The Founding Fathers of the United States often criticised direct democracy, which in their view often came without the protection of a constitution enshrining inalienable rights; James Madison argued, especially in The Federalist No. 10, that what distinguished a direct democracy from a republic was that the former became weaker as it got larger and suffered more violently from the effects of faction, whereas a republic could get stronger as it got larger and combats faction by its very structure.

prompts: A liberal democracy is a representative democracy in which the ability of the elected representatives to exercise
baseline: A liberal democracy is a representative democracy in which the ability of the elected representatives to exercise decision-making power is subject to the rule of law, and moderated by a constitution or laws that emphasise the protection of the rights and freedoms of individuals, and which places constraints on the leaders and on the extent to which the will of the majority can be exercised against the rights of minorities (see civil liberties).

prompts: In a liberal democracy , it is possible for some
baseline: In a liberal democracy, it is possible for some large-scale decisions to emerge from the many individual decisions that citizens are free to make.

prompts: Socialist thought has several different views
baseline: Socialist thought has several different views on democracy.

baseline: Many democratic socialists and social democrats believe in a form of participatory, industrial, economic and/or workplace democracy combined with a representative democracy.

baseline: Within Marxist orthodoxy there is a hostility to what is commonly called "liberal democracy", which is referred to as parliamentary democracy because of its centralised nature.

baseline: Because of orthodox Marxists' desire to eliminate the political elitism they see in capitalism, Marxists, Leninists and Trotskyists believe in direct democracy implemented through a system of communes (which are sometimes called soviets).

baseline: This system can begin with workplace democracy and ultimately manifests itself as council democracy.

baseline: To many anarchists, the only form of democracy considered acceptable is direct democracy.

prompts: Pierre - Joseph Proudhon argued that the only acceptable form of direct democracy is one in which it is recognised that majority decisions
baseline: Pierre-Joseph Proudhon argued that the only acceptable form of direct democracy is one in which it is recognised that majority decisions are not binding on the minority, even when unanimous.

prompts: However , anarcho - communist Murray Bookchin criticised individualist anarchists for
baseline: However, anarcho-communist Murray Bookchin criticised individualist anarchists for opposing democracy, and says "majority rule" is consistent with anarchism.

prompts: Some anarcho - communists oppose the majoritarian nature of direct democracy , feeling that it can
baseline: Some anarcho-communists oppose the majoritarian nature of direct democracy, feeling that it can impede individual liberty and opt-in favour of a non-majoritarian form of consensus democracy, similar to Proudhon's position on direct democracy.

baseline: The technique was in widespread use in Athenian Democracy and Renaissance Florence and is still used in modern jury selection and citizens' assemblies.

prompts: Consociational democracy , also called consociationalism , is a form of
baseline: Consociational democracy, also called consociationalism, is a form of democracy based on power-sharing formula between elites representing the social groups within the society.

baseline: A consociational democracy allows for simultaneous majority votes in two or more ethno-religious constituencies, and policies are enacted only if they gain majority support from both or all of them.

baseline: The Qualified majority voting rule in European Council of Ministers is a consociational democracy approach for supranational democracies.

baseline: A consociational democracy requires consensus of representatives, while consensus democracy requires consensus of electorate.

baseline: Consensus democracy requires consensus decision-making and supermajority to obtain a larger support than majority.

baseline: In contrast, in majoritarian democracy minority opinions can potentially be ignored by vote-winning majorities.

prompts: Inclusive democracy is a political theory and political project that aims for direct democracy
baseline: Inclusive democracy is a political theory and political project that aims for direct democracy in all fields of social life: political democracy in the form of face-to-face assemblies which are confederated, economic democracy in a stateless, moneyless and marketless economy, democracy in the social realm, i.e. self-management in places of work and education, and ecological democracy which aims to reintegrate society and nature.

prompts: The theoretical project of inclusive democracy emerged from the work
baseline: The theoretical project of inclusive democracy emerged from the work of political philosopher Takis Fotopoulos in "Towards An Inclusive Democracy" and was further developed in the journal Democracy & Nature and its successor The International Journal of Inclusive Democracy.

prompts: A Parpolity or Participatory Polity is a theoretical form of democracy that is ruled by a Nested
baseline: A Parpolity or Participatory Polity is a theoretical form of democracy that is ruled by a Nested Council structure.

baseline: Cosmopolitan democracy, also known as Global democracy or World Federalism, is a political system in which democracy is implemented on a global scale, either directly or through representatives.

baseline: By contrast, in a cosmopolitan democracy, the people who are affected by decisions also have a say in them.

baseline: According to its supporters, any attempt to solve global problems is undemocratic without some form of cosmopolitan democracy.

baseline: The general principle of cosmopolitan democracy is to expand some or all of the values and norms of democracy, including the rule of law; the non-violent resolution of conflicts; and equality among citizens, beyond the limits of the state.

prompts: Cosmopolitan Democracy has been promoted , among others
baseline: Cosmopolitan Democracy has been promoted, among others, by physicist Albert Einstein, writer Kurt Vonnegut, columnist George Monbiot, and professors David Held and Daniele Archibugi.

baseline: The creation of the International Criminal Court in 2003 was seen as a major step forward by many supporters of this type of cosmopolitan democracy.

baseline: Creative Democracy is advocated by American philosopher John Dewey.

baseline: The main idea about Creative Democracy is that democracy encourages individual capacity building and the interaction among the society.

baseline: Dewey argues that democracy is a way of life in his work of "Creative Democracy: The Task Before Us" and an experience built on faith in human nature, faith in human beings, and faith in working with others.

prompts: Democracy , in Dewey 's view , is a moral ideal requiring actual effort and
baseline: Democracy, in Dewey's view, is a moral ideal requiring actual effort and work by people; it is not an institutional concept that exists outside of ourselves. "The task of democracy", Dewey concludes, "is forever that of creation of a freer and more humane experience in which all share and to which all contribute".

baseline: Green: countries that claim to be a democracy  Red: countries that do not claim to be democratic (only Saudi Arabia, Oman, the UAE, Qatar, Brunei, Afghanistan, and the Vatican do not claim to be democratic as of 2022)

baseline: Guided democracy is a form of democracy that incorporates regular popular elections, but which often carefully "guides" the choices offered to the electorate in a manner that may reduce the ability of the electorate to truly determine the type of government exercised over them.

baseline: Russian politicians have referred to their government as having only one center of power/ authority, as opposed to most other forms of democracy which usually attempt to incorporate two or more naturally competing sources of authority within the same government.

baseline: It has often been assumed that democracy causes peace, but this study shows that, historically, peace has almost always predated the establishment of democracy.

baseline: Dahl argues that the fundamental democratic principle is that, when it comes to binding collective decisions, each person in a political community is entitled to have his/her interests be given equal consideration (not necessarily that all people are equally satisfied by the collective decision).

prompts: Unlike aggregative democracy , deliberative democracy holds that , for
baseline: Unlike aggregative democracy, deliberative democracy holds that, for a democratic decision to be legitimate, it must be preceded by authentic deliberation, not merely the aggregation of preferences that occurs in voting.

baseline: Some modern democracies that are predominantly representative in nature also heavily rely upon forms of political action that are directly democratic.

baseline: A 2019 study by Acemoglu and others estimated that countries switching to democratic from authoritarian rule had on average a 20% higher GDP after 25 years than if they had remained authoritarian.

baseline: Political scientist David Stasavage links the fragmentation of Europe, and its subsequent democratization, to the manner in which the Roman Empire collapsed: Roman territory was conquered by small fragmented groups of Germanic tribes, thus leading to the creation of small political units where rulers were relatively weak and needed the consent of the governed to ward off foreign threats.

baseline: We suppose that it was Tocqueville’s work and not least its title that strongly associated the notion of democracy with the American system and, ultimately, with representative government and universal suffrage.

baseline: Tocqueville speculates on the future of democracy in the United States, discussing possible threats to democracy and possible dangers of democracy.

baseline: Emergent democracy was coined to stand in contrast to more traditional forms of democracy, such as representative democracy and direct democracy.

baseline: Empowered democracy is a form of social-democratic arrangements developed by Brazilian philosopher and politician Roberto Mangabeira Unger, who first published his theories in 1987.

baseline: The theory of empowered democracy has received widespread critical acclaim.

baseline: In local communities, empowered democracy would make capital and technology available through rotating capital funds, which would encourage entrepreneurship and innovation.

baseline: Empowered democracy is a form of social-democratic arrangements developed by Brazilian philosopher and politician Roberto Mangabeira Unger, who first published his theories in 1987.

baseline: Theorized in response to the repressiveness and rigidity of contemporary liberal democratic society, the theory of empowered democracy envisions a more open and more plastic set of social institutions through which individuals and groups can interact, propose change, and effectively empower themselves to transform social, economic, and political structures.

prompts: Popular democracy is a notion of direct democracy based on referendums and
baseline: Popular democracy is a notion of direct democracy based on referendums and other devices of empowerment and concretization of popular will.

baseline: Some figures, like TV documentary producer, director and writer Colin Thomas, see the Levellers, resistance of groups to both the Stuart monarchy and Oliver Cromwell's English Republic as early popular democracy advocacy groups.

baseline: Thomas Paine's Common Sense is sometimes considered to defend a form of popular democracy.

baseline: William Jennings Bryan may be considered a popular democrat for his support of a democracy based on popular sovereignty.

baseline: In 1969 Muammar al-Gaddafi overthrew the pro-western monarchy and created a system he claimed to be a popular democracy.

baseline: Similarly to Gaddafi, Hafez al-Assad, officially ended the one party state of Ba'ath Syria created by the 1963 coup d'état in 1970, declaring the creation of a multi-party popular democracy.

baseline: In 1975 Al Gaddafi wrote The Green Book, where he defends his political system as a form of "direct and popular democracy" based on the will of the people instead of representative parliaments.

baseline: After the fall of Ferdinand Marcos in 1986, a research and advocacy centre called the Institute for Popular Democracy was created who frequently criticizes "elite politics" and defends reformist local social movements.

baseline: Some Burkinabé Communists founded a group who supported a Marxist-Leninist People's Democracy (though with a free-market economic plan) in 1989, the Organization for Popular Democracy - Labour Movement.

baseline: Former Venezuelan president Hugo Chávez was sometimes considered to either be practicing or simulating popular democracy.

baseline: Participatory budget and the policies of the Porto Alegre Forum are also associated with popular democracy by some left-wing authors.

baseline: As the ideal of popular democracy came out of prepositions of Populism (ex: popular rule in democracy is fairer than elitist parliaments; decisions by general referendums are fairer than decisions by limited groups like parliaments and governments), and as platforms of certain groups claiming to be popular democratic are very similar to those of various democratic and undemocratic populist movements, there is discussion on the relation between both political philosophies.

baseline: The Nepalese Maoists also support a socialist, non-elitist, form of popular democracy, which may be understood as a form of Maoist people's democracy but based more on popular participation and less on Vanguard parties.

baseline: Whitman wrote Democratic Vistas in answer to criticism of universal suffrage and full democracy of Thomas Carlyle in Latter-Day Pamphlets, who considered the popular democratic system to be too many rights given to uneducated masses of the people, as rule should be kept in the hands of highly educated people and aristocrats.

baseline: The idea of majoritarian, popular-will based democracy has been accused of facilitating the persecution of Sri Lankan Tamils.

baseline: Other limitations of popular democracy have been indicated in its relation to other social movements (as feminism and trade unionism).

baseline: The concept evolved out of the political philosophy of populism, as a fully democratic version of this popular empowerment ideology, but since it has become independent of it, and some even discuss if they are antagonistic or unrelated now (see Values).

baseline: Václav Havel's civil-society-centered democratic Czechoslovakia was considered another form of popular democracy by some.

baseline: In 1996 the popular democratic Organization for Popular Democracy - Labour Movement created the Congress for Democracy and Progress, being the current ruling party in Burkina Faso.

baseline: The internet is sometimes considered as a vital part or an example of modern popular democratic practices.

prompts: As the ideal of popular democracy came out of prepositions
baseline: As the ideal of popular democracy came out of prepositions of Populism (ex: popular rule in democracy is fairer than elitist parliaments; decisions by general referendums are fairer than decisions by limited groups like parliaments and governments), and as platforms of certain groups claiming to be popular democratic are very similar to those of various democratic and undemocratic populist movements, there is discussion on the relation between both political philosophies.

prompts: Taking advantage of the vagueness of the concept many parties in a wide range of ideologies call themselves Popular Democratic
baseline: Taking advantage of the vagueness of the concept many parties in a wide range of ideologies call themselves Popular Democratic Party, Popular Democrat Party or People's Democratic Party, or even Democratic Popular Party or Democratic People's Party and support or claim to support popular sovereignty in some form of popular democracy.

prompts: Whitman wrote Democratic Vistas in answer to criticism of universal suffrage and full democracy of Thomas Carlyle in Latter - Day Pamphlets , who considered the popular democratic
baseline: Whitman wrote Democratic Vistas in answer to criticism of universal suffrage and full democracy of Thomas Carlyle in Latter-Day Pamphlets, who considered the popular democratic system to be too many rights given to uneducated masses of the people, as rule should be kept in the hands of highly educated people and aristocrats.

prompts: Liberal democracy , western - style democracy , or substantive democracy is a form of
baseline: Liberal democracy, western-style democracy, or substantive democracy is a form of government that combines the organization of a representative democracy with ideas of liberal political philosophy.

prompts: Common elements within a liberal democracy are : elections between
baseline: Common elements within a liberal democracy are: elections between or among multiple distinct political parties, a separation of powers into different branches of government, the rule of law in everyday life as part of an open society, a market economy with private property, universal suffrage, and the equal protection of human rights, civil rights, civil liberties, and political freedoms for all citizens.

prompts: Substantive democracy refers to substantive rights and substantive laws , which can include substantive equality ,
baseline: Substantive democracy refers to substantive rights and substantive laws, which can include substantive equality, the equality of outcome for subgroups in society.

prompts: A liberal democracy may take various and mixed constitutional forms : it may be a constitutional monarchy
baseline: A liberal democracy may take various and mixed constitutional forms: it may be a constitutional monarchy or a republic.

prompts: Liberal democracy traces its origins —
baseline: Liberal democracy traces its origins—and its name—to the Age of Enlightenment.

prompts: After a period of expansion in the second half of the 20th century , liberal democracy became a prevalent political
baseline: After a period of expansion in the second half of the 20th century, liberal democracy became a prevalent political system in the world.

prompts: Liberal democracy emphasizes the separation of
baseline: Liberal democracy emphasizes the separation of powers, an independent judiciary, and a system of checks and balances between branches of government.

prompts: Liberal democracy traces its origins —
baseline: Liberal democracy traces its origins—and its name—to 18th-century Europe, during the Age of Enlightenment.

prompts: The possibility of democracy had not been a seriously considered
baseline: The possibility of democracy had not been a seriously considered political theory since classical antiquity and the widely held belief was that democracies would be inherently unstable and chaotic in their policies due to the changing whims of the people.

prompts: It was further believed that democracy was contrary to human nature , as human beings were seen to be inherently
baseline: It was further believed that democracy was contrary to human nature, as human beings were seen to be inherently evil, violent and in need of a strong leader to restrain their destructive impulses.

prompts: The conservative monarchists who opposed liberalism and democracy saw themselves as defenders
baseline: The conservative monarchists who opposed liberalism and democracy saw themselves as defenders of traditional values and the natural order of things and their criticism of democracy seemed vindicated when Napoleon Bonaparte took control of the young French Republic, reorganized it into the first French Empire and proceeded to conquer most of Europe.

prompts: Napoleon was eventually defeated and the Holy Alliance was formed in Europe to
baseline: Napoleon was eventually defeated and the Holy Alliance was formed in Europe to prevent any further spread of liberalism or democracy.

prompts: The Dominions of the British Empire became laboratories for liberal
baseline: The Dominions of the British Empire became laboratories for liberal democracy from the mid 19th century onward.

prompts: Ståhlberg ( 1865–1952 ) , the first President of the Republic of Finland , defined Finland 's anchoring
baseline: Ståhlberg (1865–1952), the first President of the Republic of Finland, defined Finland's anchoring as a country defending liberal democracy.

prompts: Reforms and revolutions helped move most European countries
baseline: Reforms and revolutions helped move most European countries towards liberal democracy.

prompts: At the same time , a number of non - liberal ideologies developed that took the
baseline: At the same time, a number of non-liberal ideologies developed that took the concept of liberal democracy and made it their own.

prompts: The political spectrum changed ; traditional monarchy became more and more
baseline: The political spectrum changed; traditional monarchy became more and more a fringe view and liberal democracy became more and more mainstream.

prompts: By the end of the 19th century , liberal democracy was no longer only
baseline: By the end of the 19th century, liberal democracy was no longer only a liberal idea, but an idea supported by many different ideologies.

prompts: After World War I and especially after World War II , liberal democracy achieved a dominant position
baseline: After World War I and especially after World War II, liberal democracy achieved a dominant position among theories of government and is now endorsed by the vast majority of the political spectrum.

prompts: Although liberal democracy was originally put forward by Enlightenment liberals , the relationship between democracy and liberalism has been controversial since the
baseline: Although liberal democracy was originally put forward by Enlightenment liberals, the relationship between democracy and liberalism has been controversial since the beginning and was problematized in the 20th century.

prompts: In his book Freedom and Equality in a Liberal Democratic State , Jasper Doomen posited that freedom and
baseline: In his book Freedom and Equality in a Liberal Democratic State, Jasper Doomen posited that freedom and equality are necessary for a liberal democracy.

prompts: In his book The End of History and the Last Man , Francis Fukuyama says that since the
baseline: In his book The End of History and the Last Man, Francis Fukuyama says that since the French Revolution, liberal democracy has repeatedly proven to be a fundamentally better system (ethically, politically, economically) than any of the alternatives, and that democracy will become more and more prevalent in the long term, although it may suffer temporary setbacks.

prompts: The research institute Freedom House today simply defines liberal democracy as
baseline: The research institute Freedom House today simply defines liberal democracy as an electoral democracy also protecting civil liberties.

prompts: The common justification for these limits is that they are
baseline: The common justification for these limits is that they are necessary to guarantee the existence of democracy, or the existence of the freedoms themselves.

prompts: Opinion is divided on how far democracy can extend to include the
baseline: Opinion is divided on how far democracy can extend to include the enemies of democracy in the democratic process.

prompts: If relatively small numbers of people are excluded from such freedoms
baseline: If relatively small numbers of people are excluded from such freedoms for these reasons, a country may still be seen as a liberal democracy.

prompts: At least in theory , opponents of democracy are also allowed due process under
baseline: At least in theory, opponents of democracy are also allowed due process under the rule of law.

prompts: For a political regime to be considered a liberal democracy
baseline: For a political regime to be considered a liberal democracy it must contain in its governing over a nation-state the provision of civil rights- the non-discrimination in the provision of public goods such as justice, security, education and health- in addition to, political rights- the guarantee of free and fair electoral contests, which allow the winners of such contests to determine policy subject to the constraints established by other rights, when these are provided- and property rights- which protect asset holders and investors against expropriation by the state or other groups.

prompts: In this way , liberal democracy is set apart from electoral
baseline: In this way, liberal democracy is set apart from electoral democracy, as free and fair elections – the hallmark of electoral democracy – can be separated from equal treatment and non-discrimination – the hallmarks of liberal democracy.

prompts: In liberal democracy , an elected government can not discriminate against specific individuals
baseline: In liberal democracy, an elected government cannot discriminate against specific individuals or groups when it administers justice, protects basic rights such as freedom of assembly and free speech, provides for collective security, or distributes economic and social benefits.

prompts: According to Seymour Martin Lipset , although they are not part of the system of government as such , a modicum of individual and economic freedoms , which result in the formation
baseline: According to Seymour Martin Lipset, although they are not part of the system of government as such, a modicum of individual and economic freedoms, which result in the formation of a significant middle class and a broad and flourishing civil society, are seen as pre-conditions for liberal democracy.

prompts: For countries without a strong tradition of democratic majority rule , the introduction of free elections alone has rarely been sufficient to achieve a transition from
baseline: For countries without a strong tradition of democratic majority rule, the introduction of free elections alone has rarely been sufficient to achieve a transition from dictatorship to democracy; a wider shift in the political culture and gradual formation of the institutions of democratic government are needed.

prompts: There are various examples — for instance , in Latin America — of countries that were able to sustain democracy only temporarily
baseline: There are various examples—for instance, in Latin America—of countries that were able to sustain democracy only temporarily or in a limited fashion until wider cultural changes established the conditions under which democracy could flourish.

prompts: The term means in essence that all sides in a democracy share a common commitment
baseline: The term means in essence that all sides in a democracy share a common commitment to its basic values.

prompts: One requirement of liberal democracy is political equality amongst voters ( ensuring that all voices and all votes count equally ) and that these can properly influence government policy ,
baseline: One requirement of liberal democracy is political equality amongst voters (ensuring that all voices and all votes count equally) and that these can properly influence government policy, requiring quality procedure and quality content of debate that provides an accountable result, this may apply within elections or to procedures between elections.

prompts: The concept of freedom used in the survey is closely connected to liberal democracy
baseline: The concept of freedom used in the survey is closely connected to liberal democracy.

prompts: One observation is that democracy became
baseline: One observation is that democracy became widespread only after the Industrial Revolution and the introduction of capitalism.

prompts: On the other hand , the Industrial Revolution started in England which
baseline: On the other hand, the Industrial Revolution started in England which was one of the most democratic nations for its time within its own borders, but this democracy was very limited and did not apply to the colonies which contributed significantly to the wealth.

prompts: There are also other studies suggesting that more democracy increases economic freedom ,
baseline: There are also other studies suggesting that more democracy increases economic freedom, although a few find no or even a small negative effect.

prompts: Some argue that economic growth due to its empowerment of citizens will ensure a transition to
baseline: Some argue that economic growth due to its empowerment of citizens will ensure a transition to democracy in countries such as Cuba.

prompts: A 2006 meta - analysis found that democracy has no direct effect
baseline: A 2006 meta-analysis found that democracy has no direct effect on economic growth.

prompts: Democracy is associated with higher human
baseline: Democracy is associated with higher human capital accumulation, lower inflation, lower political instability and higher economic freedom.

prompts: One argument for democracy is that by creating a system where
baseline: One argument for democracy is that by creating a system where the public can remove administrations, without changing the legal basis for government, democracy aims at reducing political uncertainty and instability and assuring citizens that however much they may disagree with present policies, they will be given a regular chance to change those who are in power, or change policies with which they disagree.

prompts: One notable feature of liberal democracies is that their opponents
baseline: One notable feature of liberal democracies is that their opponents (those groups who wish to abolish liberal democracy) rarely win elections.

prompts: Advocates use this as an argument to support their view that
baseline: Advocates use this as an argument to support their view that liberal democracy is inherently stable and can usually only be overthrown by external force, while opponents argue that the system is inherently stacked against them despite its claims to impartiality.

prompts: In the past , it was feared that democracy could
baseline: In the past, it was feared that democracy could be easily exploited by leaders with dictatorial aspirations, who could get themselves elected into power.

prompts: By definition , a liberal democracy implies that power is
baseline: By definition, a liberal democracy implies that power is not concentrated.

prompts: If the democracy is attacked , then no consent is usually required for defensive operations
baseline: If the democracy is attacked, then no consent is usually required for defensive operations.

prompts: Research by the World Bank suggests that political institutions are extremely important in determining the prevalence of
baseline: Research by the World Bank suggests that political institutions are extremely important in determining the prevalence of corruption: (long term) democracy, parliamentary systems, political stability and freedom of the press are all associated with lower corruption.

prompts: Prominent economist Amartya Sen has noted that no functioning democracy has ever
baseline: Prominent economist Amartya Sen has noted that no functioning democracy has ever suffered a large scale famine.

prompts: Democracy correlates with a higher
baseline: Democracy correlates with a higher score on the Human Development Index and a lower score on the human poverty index.

prompts: Several health indicators ( life expectancy and infant and maternal mortality ) have a stronger and
baseline: Several health indicators (life expectancy and infant and maternal mortality) have a stronger and more significant association with democracy than they have with GDP per capita, rise of the public sector or income inequality.

prompts: There are various criticisms of the theory , including at least as
baseline: There are various criticisms of the theory, including at least as many refutations as alleged proofs of the theory, some 200 deviant cases, failure to treat democracy as a multidimensional concept and that correlation is not causation.

prompts: Rudolph Rummel 's Power Kills says that liberal democracy
baseline: Rudolph Rummel's Power Kills says that liberal democracy, among all types of regimes, minimizes political violence and is a method of nonviolence.

prompts: Rummel attributes this firstly to democracy instilling an attitude of
baseline: Rummel attributes this firstly to democracy instilling an attitude of tolerance of differences, an acceptance of losing and a positive outlook towards conciliation and compromise.

prompts: A study published by the British Academy , on Violence and Democracy , argues that in practice
baseline: A study published by the British Academy, on Violence and Democracy, argues that in practice, liberal democracy has not stopped those running the state from exerting acts of violence both within and outside their borders.

prompts: In Athenian democracy , some public offices were randomly allocated to citizens ,
baseline: In Athenian democracy, some public offices were randomly allocated to citizens, in order to inhibit the effects of plutocracy.

prompts: The results provide substantial support for
baseline: The results provide substantial support for theories of Economic-Elite Domination and for theories of Biased Pluralism, but not for theories of Majoritarian Electoral Democracy or Majoritarian Pluralism."

prompts: This may cause conflict with liberal democracy and some of its core principles , such as freedom , if individuals are not entirely free since their governments are seizing that level of
baseline: This may cause conflict with liberal democracy and some of its core principles, such as freedom, if individuals are not entirely free since their governments are seizing that level of control on media sites.

prompts: The notion that the media is used to indoctrinate the
baseline: The notion that the media is used to indoctrinate the public is also shared by Yascha Mounk's The People Vs Democracy which states that the government benefits from the public having a relatively similar worldview and that this one-minded ideal is one of the principles in which Liberal Democracy stands.

prompts: A persistent libertarian and monarchist critique of democracy is the claim that
baseline: A persistent libertarian and monarchist critique of democracy is the claim that it encourages the elected representatives to change the law without necessity and in particular to pour forth a flood of new laws (as described in Herbert Spencer's The Man Versus The State).

prompts: Supporters of democracy point to the complex bureaucracy and regulations that has occurred in dictatorships ,
baseline: Supporters of democracy point to the complex bureaucracy and regulations that has occurred in dictatorships, like many of the former communist states.

prompts: The term " red tape " is a synonym of
baseline: The term "red tape" is a synonym of slow bureaucratic functioning that hinders quick results in a liberal democracy.

prompts: Besides the regular review of governing entities , short - term focus in a democracy could also be the result of
baseline: Besides the regular review of governing entities, short-term focus in a democracy could also be the result of collective short-term thinking.

prompts: However , such an argument could apply to both direct
baseline: However, such an argument could apply to both direct democracy or representative democracy.

prompts: In her book World on Fire , Yale Law School professor Amy Chua posits that " when
baseline: In her book World on Fire, Yale Law School professor Amy Chua posits that "when free market democracy is pursued in the presence of a market-dominant minority, the almost invariable result is backlash.

prompts: The second is a backlash against
baseline: The second is a backlash against democracy by forces favorable to the market-dominant minority.

prompts: The Athenian democracy and the early United States practiced slavery , and
baseline: The Athenian democracy and the early United States practiced slavery, and even proponents of liberal democracy in the 17th and 18th century were often pro-slavery, which is contradictory of a liberal democracy.

prompts: Proponents of democracy make a number of defenses concerning " tyranny of
baseline: Proponents of democracy make a number of defenses concerning "tyranny of the majority".

prompts: Proponents of democracy argue that empirical statistical evidence strongly shows that more democracy
baseline: Proponents of democracy argue that empirical statistical evidence strongly shows that more democracy leads to less internal violence and mass murder by the government.

prompts: Marxists and communists , as well as some non - Marxist socialists and anarchists , argue that liberal democracy
baseline: Marxists and communists, as well as some non-Marxist socialists and anarchists, argue that liberal democracy under capitalism is constitutively class-based and therefore can never be democratic or participatory.

prompts: They refer to it as " bourgeois democracy " because they say that ultimately ,
baseline: They refer to it as "bourgeois democracy" because they say that ultimately, politicians fight mainly for the interests of the bourgeoisie.

prompts: As such , liberal democracy is said to represent "
baseline: As such, liberal democracy is said to represent "the rule of capital".

prompts: Vladimir Lenin once argued that liberal democracy had simply been used to give an
baseline: Vladimir Lenin once argued that liberal democracy had simply been used to give an illusion of democracy whilst maintaining the dictatorship of the bourgeoisie, giving as an example the United States's representative democracy which he said consisted of "spectacular and meaningless duels between two bourgeois parties" led by "multimillionaires".

prompts: Some socialists , such as The Left party in Germany , say that liberal democracy
baseline: Some socialists, such as The Left party in Germany, say that liberal democracy is a dishonest farce used to keep the masses from realizing that their will is irrelevant in the political process.

prompts: The Chinese Communist Party political concept of whole - process people 's democracy criticizes liberal democracy for
baseline: The Chinese Communist Party political concept of whole-process people's democracy criticizes liberal democracy for excessively relying on procedural formalities without genuinely reflecting the interests of the people.

prompts: Under this primarily consequentialist concept , the most important criteria for a democracy is whether it can
baseline: Under this primarily consequentialist concept, the most important criteria for a democracy is whether it can "solve the people's real problems", while a system in which "the people are awakened only for voting" is not truly democratic.

prompts: For example , the Chinese government 's 2021 white paper China : Democracy that Works criticizes liberal democracy 's
baseline: For example, the Chinese government's 2021 white paper China: Democracy that Works criticizes liberal democracy's shortcoming based on principles of whole process people's democracy.

prompts: Authoritarianism is perceived by many to be a direct threat to the liberalised democracy practised in many countries
baseline: Authoritarianism is perceived by many to be a direct threat to the liberalised democracy practised in many countries.

prompts: In their book ' Authoritarianism Goes Global : The Challenge to Democracy ' they claim that Beijing confronts
baseline: In their book 'Authoritarianism Goes Global: The Challenge to Democracy' they claim that Beijing confronts the United States by building its navy and missile force and promotes the creation of global institutions designed to exclude American and European influence; as such authoritarian states pose a threat to liberal democracy as they seek to remake the world in their own image.

prompts: There are ongoing debates surrounding the effect that war may have on liberal democracy , and whether it cultivates or inhibits democratization
baseline: There are ongoing debates surrounding the effect that war may have on liberal democracy, and whether it cultivates or inhibits democratization.

prompts: Several studies have concluded that terrorism is most common in nations with intermediate political freedom , meaning countries transitioning from
baseline: Several studies have concluded that terrorism is most common in nations with intermediate political freedom, meaning countries transitioning from autocratic governance to democracy.

prompts: Populism is a form of majoritarianism , threatening some of the
baseline: Populism is a form of majoritarianism, threatening some of the core principles of liberal democracy such as the rights of the individual.

prompts: Populism is a particular threat to the liberal democracy because it exploits the weaknesses of
baseline: Populism is a particular threat to the liberal democracy because it exploits the weaknesses of the liberal democratic system.

prompts: Another reason that populism is a threat to liberal democracy is because it exploits
baseline: Another reason that populism is a threat to liberal democracy is because it exploits the inherent differences between 'Democracy' and 'Liberalism'.

prompts: For liberal democracy to be effective , a degree of compromise is required as protecting the
baseline: For liberal democracy to be effective, a degree of compromise is required as protecting the rights of the individual take precedence if they are threatened by the will of the majority, more commonly known as a tyranny of the majority.

prompts: Majoritarianism is so ingrained in
baseline: Majoritarianism is so ingrained in populism that this core value of a liberal democracy is under threat.

prompts: This therefore brings into question how effectively liberal democracy can defend itself from populism
baseline: This therefore brings into question how effectively liberal democracy can defend itself from populism.

prompts: According to Takis Papas in his work Populism and Liberal Democracy : A Comparative and Theoretical Analysis , " democracy has two opposites ,
baseline: According to Takis Papas in his work Populism and Liberal Democracy: A Comparative and Theoretical Analysis, "democracy has two opposites, one liberal, the other populist".

prompts: This case study also illustrates the potential threat populism can pose to a liberal
baseline: This case study also illustrates the potential threat populism can pose to a liberal democracy with the movement heavily relying on disdain for the media.

prompts: However , liberal democratic ideals soon became widespread among the
baseline: However, liberal democratic ideals soon became widespread among the general population and over the 19th century traditional monarchy was forced on a continuous defensive and withdrawal.

prompts: In his book Freedom and Equality in a Liberal Democratic State , Jasper Doomen posited that freedom and
baseline: In his book Freedom and Equality in a Liberal Democratic State, Jasper Doomen posited that freedom and equality are necessary for a liberal democracy.

prompts: Political freedom is a central concept
baseline: Political freedom is a central concept in history and political thought and one of the most important features of democratic societies.

prompts: The concept of political freedom is closely connected with the concepts
baseline: The concept of political freedom is closely connected with the concepts of civil liberties and human rights, which in democratic societies are usually afforded legal protection from the state.

baseline: Liberal democracies are contrasted with illiberal democracies and dictatorships.

baseline: Multi-party systems with at least two persistent, viable political parties are characteristic of liberal democracies.

baseline: Some liberal democracies, especially those with large populations, use federalism (also known as vertical separation of powers) in order to prevent abuse and increase public input by dividing governing powers between municipal, provincial and national governments.

baseline: The characteristics of liberal democracies are correlated with increased political stability, lower corruption, better management of resources, and better health indicators such as life expectancy and infant mortality.

baseline: Liberal democracies usually have universal suffrage, granting all adult citizens the right to vote regardless of ethnicity, sex, property ownership, race, age, sexuality, gender, income, social status, or religion.

baseline: According to a study by Coppedge and Reinicke, at least 85% of democracies provided for universal suffrage.

baseline: Liberal democracies are susceptible to democratic backsliding and this is taking place or has taken place in several countries, including, but not limited to, the United States, Poland, Hungary, and Israel.
